posts.name: Brian Hagan
posts.cooked:
We have a couple of questions at the end of our rookie season to prepare for next year.

What do we need to buy for a swerve drive? (e.g. does AndyMark have a bundle ?)

We would like to switch to brushless motors. What should we purchase for our drive, climber, other?

Do you have to use Spark Max? We have one on each motor (7) and had to replace 4 this year because they stop working.  These were brand new and caused us to stop during several matches.

posts.name: Dan Langdon
posts.cooked:
There are multiple cots Swerve modules out there.  We use SDS , but WCP and Rev both offer good kits.  The frame is then just 1x2 tubing.  No one offers a KOP chassis type kit that I am aware of, but construction of a swerve frame is easy.

There are multiple cots Swerve modules out there.  We use SDS , but WCP and Rev both offer good kits.  The frame is then just 1x2 tubing.  No one offers a KOP chassis type kit that I am aware of, but construction of a swerve frame is easy.

We have become real fans of the Kraken this year.  In most cases I would recommend full size brushless vs the Neo 550.  We are very likely to stick to the Kraken for everything next year.

We have become real fans of the Kraken this year.  In most cases I would recommend full size brushless vs the Neo 550.  We are very likely to stick to the Kraken for everything next year.

With Kraken and Falcons they have an integrated motor controller.  We the Noes and Vortexs you will have to purchase a rev motor controller to use them.  So the answer is yes and no depending on your motor choices from above.

With Kraken and Falcons they have an integrated motor controller.  We the Noes and Vortexs you will have to purchase a rev motor controller to use them.  So the answer is yes and no depending on your motor choices from above.

posts.name: MARS_James
posts.cooked:
woodworker2001:

Vortexs you will have to purchase a rev motor controller to use them

Vortex have an integrated controller

posts.name: David B
posts.cooked: You need a sprak flex or spark max iirc?

posts.name: Dan Langdon
posts.cooked: I was more referring to an integrated controller as one that couldnt be removed and didnt have to be purchased seperately

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked: The Vortex can either use the “Spark Flex” controllers which “bolts on” to the motor or it can use the “Solo adapter” which also bolts on and allows the use of a Sparkmax.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked:
haganbs:

Do you have to use Spark Max? We have one on each motor (7) and had to replace 4 this year because they stop working. These were brand new and caused us to stop during several matches.

This is definitely not a normal failure rate.  You should definitely figure out what is going on to cause this.

Right now, obtaining some of the newer motors is a problem.  We saw the same problem last May when we started down the swerve path.  We ended up getting the West Coast Products “Swerve X” modules in the NEO motor, Flipped, Corner Mount variant, because we could get our hands on NEOs.

posts.name: Matt Boehm
posts.cooked: Big fan of the Swerve MK4’s (no experience with the Mk4i though) and would recommend them as an option. We ran them with Falcons at L2 gearing but are probably going to be switching to Krakens next year and investigate L3 since we have been so light the past 2 years. We didn’t get them in time to use them this year so that is an off season test for us.  I personally prefer to use the same motor for everything if possible since it means for spares you only have to cover one type.  The NEO 550 is the only exception and that is purely for packaging reasons

posts.name: Rahul Yarlagadda
posts.cooked: This ends up being very game and robot dependent, but generally a spread around 13-16fps is good for most teams. Gearing faster is advantageous for a game with full field cycles like this year, but often requires you to pay much more attention to your battery health to avoid browning out.

posts.name: Brandon McDonald
posts.cooked:
First of all, love your team number (our number is 453)!

haganbs:

What do we need to buy for a swerve drive? (e.g. does AndyMark have a bundle ?)

I HIGHLY recommend the REV MaxSwerve. It has the best price point for smaller teams and so many guides and resources that help you get started. Our team was able to get a working drivetrain within about 3-4 meetings with only 5 or so people working on it. There are some issues with this module but none that are big enough that they outweigh the pros.

REV Robotics designs, builds and manufactures robotics parts and components used by students for learning about science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM). Our parts are commonly used within the FIRST Robotics Competition and the FIRST Tech...

Price: USD 300

haganbs:

Do you have to use Spark Max? We have one on each motor (7) and had to replace 4 this year because they stop working. These were brand new and caused us to stop during several matches.

This is odd. I would take the time to look into this issue and your driver station logs instead of just writing off 4 of them as “bad”. It is much more likely that you had a CAN fault or that the controllers were configured incorrectly.

posts.name: Kadir
posts.cooked:
First of all, your budget is very important for the swerve drive if you have a solid budget, I recommend buying the mk4i from SDS , since the engines are facing down, the space in your chassis will open up more and it will still be more comfortable to use

Your budget is also very important for a brushless motor, if you have a good budget, you can think of a neo or mini neo for certain mechanisms, for example, you can think of a kraken engine for the swerve drive, while neo will be enough for a simple intake mechanism, I think the neo engine will be enough for the climbing mechanism, but the only problem with the neo engine is that the sparx max motor driver can sometimes get probelms related to its sockets when it is not properly protected

If you are planning to use the neo engine, spark max becomes mandatory, but if you are not planning to use the neo engine, you do not need to use spark max

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked:
haganbs:

Which ratio set would you get?

X2 but we are considering regearing to X3

Hi! I’ve used the swerveX modules before from WCP , and while they were decent, I actually recommend using Rev MAX Swerve, as it’s a lot easier to build and service than Swerve X in my opinion.

Rev swerve comes in a bundle with all of the motors + gearboxes + motor controllers, too!

Adding on to this.

MAXSwerve comes with 3 ratios and the encoder included in the price. There is a higher speed kit that you can buy to go even faster if necessary, but you still get 3 speeds to start with.

The only point of caution is that if you are using the plastic wheels you should buy plenty . They will wear out quite fast. The new wheels are not quite as bad as the old ones, but they will go bald. Rev and TTB both sell aluminum wheels for tread if you prefer that, however.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Doubling the current limit does not make it work.

posts.custom_user_title: Doubling the current limit does not make it work.

posts.name: Adam
posts.cooked: We ran krakens with l3 this year. We are 5 pounds below max weight, and still have and excess amount of torque. It’s to the point where our wheels are constantly losing traction(partially because we’re running colsons). We’re testing some 3d printed wheels from a different thread, and also might implement a faster gear ratio if we’re not max weight next year. TLDR: l3 with krakens is plenty unless you have file cards for tread.

posts.name: Dan Langdon
posts.cooked: I would second that. We had plenty and were right at weight. Love MKS4is with L3 gear set. May Goto l4 next year with the 16 tooth pinion

posts.name: Vaughn Khouri
posts.cooked:
There are already plenty of good answers in here, just a couple things to add.

While I really like the design of MAXSwerve, it has really rough compatibility with anything other then the Neo/Neo Vortex as your drive motor. Likewise the steering motor also has to be a 550.

If you choose to use these modules you’ll be locked into Rev’s motor ecosystem for an essential part of your robot, which in my opinion does not currently meet the standard of quality control, power and reliability that is required for me to feel comfortable on the field this year. @Amicus1 can elaborate there.

For this reason I would really encourage SDS or WCP SwerveX with Krakens. Krakens are also in stock and ready to ship from WCP now, which is a huge plus! It’s the first time in a few years that there’s actually been back inventory of a BL motor. I have nothing but good things to say about the quality of the product and the software that supports it.

SDS is the more polished module in my opinion (with a lower part count), but SwerveX gives you more options in terms of drive ratios. You really can’t go wrong with either.

posts.name: Brandon McDonald
posts.cooked:
CyberClone:

locked into Rev’s motor ecosystem for an essential part of your robot, which in my opinion does not currently meet the standard of quality control, power and reliability that is required for me to feel comfortable on the field this year.

I’m curious why you feel this way. I have never seen Rev products this way so did you have a bad experience? Do you have any evidence (Empirical or Anecdotal) that you can share?

posts.name: Vaughn Khouri
posts.cooked:
I pinged @Amicus1 because he actually ran them for a couple events and saw several insane failure cases. Among those I think were several shorts from motor power to the casing, controller issues, and other things documented in their build thread .

Aside from that, cracked face plates have been a huge issue, massive shaft runout , CAN signal integrity issues , and other QC stuff that is maybe(?) resolved but teams are still having clear issues with.

Then you get into the software. REV’s equivilant of MotionMagic is still broken to the point where most people suggest just using voltage and running any control loop on the Rio. Simulation support is nonexistant, and there are still bizarre issues that somehow end up on main . Overall, there’s progress being made, but it just isn’t where it needs to be, even after a whole season. A lot of the software stuff is documented here .

Then you get into the actual power curves. Now, the truth is that BL motors are overpowered in 90% of cases, so you won’t really notice much of a difference on something like an elevator or a shooter. Well, unless you count the fact that the integrated encoder on the Neo 1/1.1 is still non ideal for precise control of a velocity control loop, especially on the default Spark filtering settings.

However, on swerve drive (and this is made worse by a game where so much of the cycle is spent driving) small gains in power can make a big difference. A common misconception is that motors in FRC are limited to 40a. In reality, the thermal breakers are incredibly forgiving. On 8033 we limit each of our drivetrain motors to 120a continuous with no issues - some teams with lighter robots run them even higher, and for incidental current you can leave it basically unlimited. So when comparing the motor power curves: image 965×581 28.7 KB Screenshot 2024-04-05 at 3.04.04 AM 1390×870 295 KB

image 965×581 28.7 KB

image 965×581 28.7 KB

Screenshot 2024-04-05 at 3.04.04 AM 1390×870 295 KB

Screenshot 2024-04-05 at 3.04.04 AM 1390×870 295 KB

We can see that a lot of power is left on the table because a Neo Vortex will only draw about 200a under absolute stall conditions. The Kraken will gladly pull more then double that, which contributes to a stall torque almost 2.5x higher. But the more important thing is how this translates to the rest of the curve - at peak output, the power is much higher on the Kraken because it is still able to draw much more current. I (think) this just comes down to the fact that the Kraken is a bigger motor with a bigger stator and more windings. (General PSA: there are a lot of people who know a lot more about motor curves then me @BoiledBurntBagel please correct me if I am wrong here)

Now does this really translate to measurable performance gain when current limits are set? Once again JS can probably answer since 6995 ran events with both. But I’ve been told by other teams that switched mid-season that it had a measurable impact on acceleration, which is especially apparent during auto.

That was a bit longer then I probably wanted it to be; I hope it was at least somewhat useful. To be 100% honest I really have nothing against REV. I love the MAXPlanetary system, MAXSpline, and their electronics are pretty great (especially with the new 22awg wago connectors!). But looking at how close this coming offseason is and the current state of things, I find it hard to recommend the Vortex and Spark Flex until I see some major changes.
